tossups.question: Three poems were wrongly attributed to this poet in Marc-Antoine Muret's ("moo-RAY'S") 1554 edition, but Muret's numbering of his work has been retained. This poet was popularized in late 17th-century France via Jean de la Chapelle's novel about his Adventures. This poet described how gods deign not to "endure the touch of clear daylight" in his longest poem, which opens by describing "the pine trees formerly grown on Mt. Pelion's summit." This Neoteric poet described the wedding of Peleus and Thetis in his sixty-fourth epyllion. A two-line poem by this poet, which notes that "I feel it happening and I am tortured," is one of his 116 carmina. This poet stated "I hate and I love" a woman whose sparrow he mourns in one poem, and who may have been Publius Clodius Pulcher's sister. For 10 points, name this poet who addressed many love poems to Lesbia.
tossups.formatted_answer: Gaius Valerius Catullus [Though only 113 of his poems survive, numbering goes up to 116 due to Muret's error noted in the first line.]
tossups.answer: Gaius Valerius Catullus [Though only 113 of his poems survive, numbering goes up to 116 due to Muret's error noted in the first line.]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The nine layers of this place took four years to traverse, with the first layer containing a river dogs carried their owners across. Objects from this place were brought to the paradise Tamoanchan where they were ground up with help from a fertility goddess. Worms in this place are used to punch holes in a conch shell filled with bees to create music. After being startled by a quail, a feathered serpent fell into a pit with the bones he'd mix with his blood to create humanity. The fire and lighting god Xolotl served as a guide through this place whose layers include Celhuecayan and Timiminalóayan. Sacrifice victims and jaguar warriors who fall in battle would accompany the rising sun instead of being sent to, for 10 points, what place for the dead in the worldview of a central Mexican civilization?
tossups.formatted_answer: Mictlan [accept answers describing the Aztec underworld, prompt on partial answers]
tossups.answer: Mictlan [accept answers describing the Aztec underworld, prompt on partial answers]

tossups.question: One of these two non-Dutch countries passed the Landsbanki Freezing Order in 2008 after a bank in the other entered receivership. A marine who committed suicide was the only causality of Operation Fork, which one of these two countries carried out on the other despite the latter's neutrality in World War II. The C.S. Forester, a vessel from one of these two countries, was seized by the other in a conflict in which the seizing country also employed trawlwire cutters. That conflict began after one of these two countries impeded on a 50-nautical mile zone as these two NATO allies disputed fishing rights in the North Atlantic during the Cod Wars. For 10 points, name these two countries, one of which experienced sulfur pollution in the Thames valley after the 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallajökull (EY-ahf-yat-la-YOH-koot-uhl) in the other.
tossups.formatted_answer: United Kingdom and Iceland [all acceptable answers may be given in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given; or U.K. in place of "United Kingdom"; or Ísland in place of "Iceland"]

tossups.question: This phenomenon cannot be imposed on bodies at rest by the Herglotz-Noether ("NUR-tur") theorem, as it is generated by Killing vectors. Langevin (LON-zhuh-van) observers view this non-contraction phenomenon, an apparent form of which for fast-moving objects is named for Penrose and Terrell. A phase shift occurs when this phenomenon affects a ring interferometer in the Sagnac (SAN-yack) effect. Applying Born rigidity to objects undergoing this phenomenon prompted the relativistic Ehrenfest (AIR-en-fest) paradox. Black holes described by the Kerr metric, but not those described by the Schwarzschild (SHVART-shild) metric, exhibit this kind of motion. A term equal to minus 2 m omega cross v is added to acceleration in reference frames undergoing this motion. Coriolis acceleration results when a reference frame undergoes - for 10 points - what type of motion, whose rate is described by angular velocity?
tossups.formatted_answer: rotation [or rotating or other word forms; or Penrose-Terrell rotation]
tossups.answer: rotation [or rotating or other word forms; or Penrose-Terrell rotation]

tossups.question: (Description acceptable.) This character dons a red chemise in a staging by Pina Bausch with a dirt-covered floor. In the Kenneth MacMillan version, a then-unknown Monica Mason premiered this role, played in the US premiere of Massine's version by a young Martha Graham. When the choreographer's sister became pregnant, this role was premiered by Maria Piltz. Per some reports, a heckler's call for a dentist was sparked by this unnamed character holding her cheeks, though others report it was directed to the "long-braided Lolitas" in general. This character is twice caught in games of "Mystic Circles." Scenes of the "Evocation" and "Ritual Action" of ancestors come between the "Glorification" of this character and the finale in which she dances herself to death. For 10 points, identify this character sacrificed at the end of a riot-sparking ballet by Stravinsky.
tossups.formatted_answer: the Chosen One [or Chosen Maiden; or descriptions of the central character who dies or is sacrificed in The Rite of Spring / Le sacre du printemps / Sacred Spring / Vesna svyashchennaya ]

tossups.question: In a story by this author, a company board hides in a bomb shelter for twelve hours, ruining a merger, after "borborygmi" (bor-boh-RIG-mi) cause the title character's stomach to repeat the sound of a siren. On a bank holiday weekend, a mattress full of money is burned by a group of boys in a story by this author. In that story by this author of "Alas, Poor Maling," Old Misery is locked in an outhouse by the Wormsley Common Gang while they methodically reduce his house to rubble. This author used the Blitz as the background for his novel about the relationship between Sarah Miles and Maurice Bendrix and for his story "The Destructors." Ida Arnold haunts a teenager who kills the newspaper employee Fred Hale in a novel by this author. For 10 points, name this author of The End of the Affair, who created gang leader Pinkie Brown in Brighton Rock.
tossups.formatted_answer: Graham Greene [Henry Graham Greene]

tossups.question: One candidate ran for this election during a tour for a best-selling book titled for a place that "Has Not Spoken Her Last Word." A majority-judgment "People's Primary" prior to this election unsuccessfully tried to nominate the Walwari leader Christiane Taubira ("chris-tee-an tau-BEER-ah"). A Jewish CNews host convicted of hate speech for calling migrant children "thieves" and "murderers" formed the Reconquest! party prior to this election. This election's eventual winner was mocked for wearing a hoodie prior to several video calls with Vladimir Putin. Eric Zemmour ("EH-rick ZEM-ur") and Valérie Pécresse ("pay-CRESS") stood in this election, which ended with a runoff in which the National Rally party was defeated for the second time in a row by En Marche! ("on marsh"). For 10 points, name this election, the second time in which Marine Le Pen ("mah-REEN luh PEN") was defeated by Emmanuel Macron (eh-MAN-yoo-ell mah-CRON").
tossups.formatted_answer: 2022 French presidential election [accept any answer indicating the most recent presidential election in France; prompt on the French election alone with "For what office?"]

tossups.question: John Zaccaro's suspicious finances affected a candidate in this election, who was the first Italian-American on a major party ticket since Al Smith. Shortly before this election cycle, Ed Harris played a younger version of a primary candidate in the film The Right Stuff. The line "prepared for peace" appeared at the end of an ad during this election that also likened global threats to a "bear in the woods." Jesse Jackson first ran for President in this election. A candidate in this election declared he wouldn't "exploit, for political purposes, my opponent's youth and inexperience" during a debate. Geraldine Ferraro was the running mate of the losing candidate in this election, who only won Washington, D.C. and his home state of Minnesota. For 10 points, name this election year in which Walter Mondale lost to incumbent Ronald Reagan.
tossups.formatted_answer: United States Presidential election of 1984

tossups.question: Walter Erwin Diewert rejected a measure of this quantity based on Debreu's coefficient. Casey Mulligan and Gary Becker theorized that increases in this quantity would decrease the size of government. This quantity is zero if the Marshallian demand is perfectly elastic. The claim that this quantity for a monopoly in manufacturing would be unlikely to exceed 0.1% of GDP was made by Arnold Harberger, who sometimes names a construct that gives this quantity as one-half times the price difference times the difference in quantity demanded. This quantity's increase represents a decrease in economic surplus, which can be caused by taxes or price ceilings and floors. A triangle on the left side of a supply and demand graph represents, for 10 points, what quantity that represents economic inefficiency when a market deviates from equilibrium?
tossups.formatted_answer: deadweight loss [or excess burden; accept DWL; accept allocative inefficiency; accept Harberger's triangle before "Harberger;" accept excess burden of taxation; prompt on economic inefficiency]
tossups.answer: deadweight loss [or excess burden; accept DWL; accept allocative inefficiency; accept Harberger's triangle before "Harberger;" accept excess burden of taxation; prompt on economic inefficiency]

tossups.question: A logarithmic unit of time named for this adjective is denoted by a capital D with a line through it. The steady-state model is underpinned by a "perfect" version of a statement named for this adjective. A quantity named for this adjective, which quantum field theories predict to be 120 orders of magnitude greater than its observed value, multiplies the metric tensor in the equations of GR. A statement named for this adjective states that on large scales, homogeneity and isotropy should be seen in the universe. A quantity named for this adjective is the "lambda" in the lambda-CDM model. Dark energy is associated with a constant named for this adjective, which Albert Einstein dismissed as his "greatest blunder." For 10 points, give this adjectival form of the name of the field that studies the origin and evolution of the universe.
tossups.formatted_answer: cosmological [or cosmological constant or cosmological principle or cosmological decade; accept cosmology and word forms; do not accept or prompt on "cosmic"]
tossups.answer: cosmological [or cosmological constant or cosmological principle or cosmological decade; accept cosmology and word forms; do not accept or prompt on "cosmic"]

tossups.question: In a 2021 novel by this author, Frances Cottrell is flirted with by the associate minister Russ Hildebrandt. This author cites Shirley Brice Heath's work on "forced transition zones" in an essay that recounts promoting a novel about St. Louis police chief S. Jammu, The Twenty-Seventh City. This author, who is currently writing the trilogy A Key To All Mythologies, described struggling to read The Recognitions by William Gaddis in the essay "Mr. Difficult." This author of a literary manifesto titled either "Perchance to Dream" or "Why Bother?" wrote a novel in which the drug Corecktall (correct-all) is used by the retired railway engineer Alfred to treat his Parkinson's disease. That novel by this author is set in St. Jude after Enid reunites the Lambert family for "one last Christmas." For 10 points, name this contemporary author of The Corrections.
tossups.formatted_answer: Jonathan Franzen [Jonathan Earl Franzen]

tossups.question: A philosopher from this modern-day country stated "I am, therefore I think" in one work's section "The Starting-Point." Christia Mercer claims that Descartes's Meditations on First Philosophy was inspired by the ideas of a thinker from this country who preached "mental prayer" in The Interior Castle. A philosopher from this country created the theory of ratio-vitalism, which supports his statement that "I am me and my circumstance." It's not the U.S., but a thinker born in this country cited "essence," "matter," "truth," and "spirit" as the The Realms of Being, and asserted that "philosophy begins in medias res" in Scepticism and Animal Faith. That thinker born in this country said that "those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it." For 10 points, name this birth country of José Ortega y Gasset and George Santayana.
tossups.formatted_answer: Kingdom of Spain [or Reino de España]

tossups.question: This procedure is indicated in patients with complete previa. This procedure may result in a higher risk of tissue transglutaminase autoantibodies and celiac disease due to the lack of microbiota acquisition. The WHO developed the Robson classification to compare rates of this procedure in different areas. The Pfannenstiel (FAH-nuhn-steel) method for this procedure is considered less safe than the Joel-Cohen method. People who have already undergone this procedure may elect either to repeat this procedure or undergo a VBAC (VEE-back). This procedure may be used on a person undergoing cardiac arrest in a resuscitative hysterotomy. Dystocia (diss-TOE-shuh) or orientation in the breech position are complications in labor that may warrant the use of this procedure. For 10 points, name this delivery technique in which an incision is made in the mother's abdomen.
tossups.formatted_answer: C-section [or Caesarean section or Caesarean delivery; prompt on incision until read; prompt on birth or delivery until read; prompt on pregnancy]

tossups.question: A form of popularism called Poporanism was promoted in this country in the 1890s. In 1848, pro-independence protestors in this country issued the Proclamation of Islaz and burned copies of the Regulamentul (reg-oo-lah-MEN-tool) Organic. The Siguranța (sig-oo-RAN-zuh) was formed in this country as a result of a 1907 uprising sometimes called the last peasant revolt in Europe. This was the northernmost country whose independence was recognized in the treaties of San Stefano and Berlin following its governance by the domnitor (dom-nee-TOR) Alexander Cuza. Though briefly restored by King Michael's Coup, this country's monarchy was abolished and replaced by the Iron Guard in 1940. This country was unified from the "Danubian principalities" of Moldavia and Wallachia. For 10 points, Vlad the Impaler is a national hero of what Eastern European country?

tossups.question: In one work, this substance surrounds a disk representing the goddess Hathor between two golden horns. This substance was added to the central piece of John LeKay's This Is My Body, This Is My Blood for the artwork In Nomine Patris. An umbrella hangs from hooks and appears in this substance in the Gagosian Gallery's Pursuit of Oblivion. The artworks The Golden Calf and The Kingdom are surrounded by this substance and were sold at the "Beautiful Inside My Head Forever" auction. An artist claimed this substance showed "Life's like this, then it stops" in the work Mother and Child Divided for Charles Saatchi. A Queensland fisherman caught an animal surrounded by this liquid in the artwork The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living. Damien Hirst encased a shark in, for 10 points, what chemical that preserves tissue?

tossups.question: This composer declared that good music writing requires a "grand line," which was explained as a "sense of flow" when popularized in another composer's book What to Listen For in Music. Aaron Copland's organ symphony was premiered by this organist. By either 10 or 12, this composer memorized all of Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier. This conductor at the premiere of Stravinsky's Dumbarton Oaks Concerto was the director of the Fontainebleau School from 1953 until dying at 92 years old. George Gershwin loved to repeat the story of this musician telling him "I can teach you nothing." This composer quit writing music after the death of Lili, a sister who was the first woman to win the Prix de Rome. tossups.formatted_answer: Nadia Boulanger

tossups.question: A man in one of this author's stories sees a white lily blossom after waiting for a century by the grave of a woman he buried. The author of the farewell poem "Thoughts on the Precipice" was a student of this author, who responded to it in a novel in which a mysterious hostess reminds the protagonist of Millais's (mill-AYS's) Ophelia. Ten Nights of Dreams is by this author, whose novel about an artist who meets O-Nami after retreating to the mountains is sometimes translated as The Grass Pillow. One of this author's protagonists witnesses the relationship between characters translated as Opula Goldfield and Avalon Coldmoon before getting drunk and drowning in a rain barrel. The protagonist of that novel by this author is the teacher Mr. Sneaze's pet. For 10 points, name this Japanese author of The Three-Cornered World and I Am A Cat.

tossups.question: The Codex Washingtonianus adds an extra verse near the end of this book known as the "Freer Logion". Clement of Alexandria claimed to have knowledge of a "secret" version of this book in the Mar Saba letter. The Wilke and Farrer hypotheses maintain that this book was the first of three to be written. This book excludes accounts that are common in the "double tradition". The sixteenth and final chapter of this book traditionally includes its "Longer Ending". Notable passages unique to this book include the Parable of the Growing Seed and an account of a naked "young man" fleeing the Garden of Gethsemane after Jesus's arrest. An explanation for the synoptic problem called the two-source hypothesis claims that the Q source and this book were used as sources. For 10 points, name this shortest of the Gospels, usually placed between Matthew and Luke.
tossups.formatted_answer: Gospel of Mark [or the Gospel according to Mark]

tossups.question: Martial arts were banned on this island in 1984 after the popularity of Bruce Lee led to the formation of many kung fu clubs. During a rebellion on this island, red laterite (LAT-eh-rite) soil was spread on the clothing of the Sakalava people. The largest ethnic group on this island was formerly divided into slaves, nobles, and commoners called andevo (ahn-DEE-veoh), andriana (ahn-dree-AH-nah), and hova. Suspected criminals on this island were forced to eat three pieces of chicken skin and poisonous tangena (tan-GAY-nah) nuts during trials by ordeal. Operation Ironclad was part of a 1942 battle named for this island, whose Merina (meh-REE-nah) Kingdom was ruled by three queens named Ranavalona (RAN-ah-vah-LOW-nah). Nazi Germany briefly considered deporting Jewish people to this island, which was the site of the Malagasy Republic. For 10 points, name this former French colony off the southeast coast of mainland Africa.
tossups.formatted_answer: Madagascar [or Madagasikara]
tossups.answer: Madagascar [or Madagasikara]

tossups.question: In 2021, Cai et. al. developed an eleven-step artificial anabolic pathway to produce this compound from carbon dioxide. When this compound is suspended in water, it forms a non-Newtonian fluid called "oobleck". The components of this compound realign themselves as it cools in a process called retrogradation. This is the primary compound found in surface sizing solutions. The intermolecular bonds between molecules of this compound are broken down in gelatinization. This compound can form dextrins when heated. This compound forms a dark blue or black complex with triiodide. This compound, made up of amylose and amylopectin, can be broken down into maltose by beta-amylase. For 10 points, name this polymer of glucose connected by alpha-glycosidic bonds, which plants use for energy storage.
tossups.formatted_answer: starch [or amylum; or corn starch]
tossups.answer: starch [or amylum; or corn starch]

tossups.question: After five characters in this novel are "linked together" by "mutual instinct," they begin to resemble "more bestial types" such as a wolf and a tortoise, which leads a character to lament that "we're the zoo." A general in this novel worries that Armitage may have talked about how he sent Richmond off to die in order to be with Leslie. A character in this novel is frightened by the feeling of seaweed on her neck because it reminds her of Cyril's hand. A phonograph recording called "the Voice" interrupts a silence in this novel to list out indictments. At the end of this novel, Vera Claythorne shoots Philip Lombard before hanging herself out of guilt. In this novel, Justice Wargrave murders guests on an island one by one based on the children's song "Ten Little Indians." For 10 points, name this mystery novel by Agatha Christie.
tossups.formatted_answer: And Then There Were None [or Ten Little Indians until it is read]

bonuses.leadin: The lawyer Constance Baker Motley has been called the "Civil Rights Queen." For 10 points each:
parts: Motley wrote the original complaint in this 1954 case, which effectively overruled Plessy v. Ferguson and struck down racial segregation in public schools.

Motley represented this man in a case whose witnesses included Robert Ellis, the registrar at the University of Mississippi. Robert F. Kennedy sent federal marshals to protect this person, who was later shot during his March Against Fear.

Motley argued in a 1963 case that this city's plan to very slowly desegregate its public recreational facilities was unconstitutional. The March Against Fear began in this city, which was led by Henry Loeb during an event that featured signs reading "I AM A MAN."
answers: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
Memphis [or Watson v. City of Memphis] [Henry Loeb was mayor during the Memphis sanitation strike.]
formatted_answers: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
Memphis [or Watson v. City of Memphis] [Henry Loeb was mayor during the Memphis sanitation strike.]

bonuses.leadin: According to Pliny the Elder's Natural History, this artist lost a contest to Parrhasius after he was tricked by a realistic painting of a curtain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist who took the best features of five different models for a painting of Helen of Troy. Aert de Gelder depicted himself as this artist "portraying an Ugly Old Woman."
Apocryphally, Zeuxis died from laughter after that old woman wanted to model as this figure. Praxiteles created a nude statue of this Greek goddess of love for her temple at Knidos.
Zeuxis allegedly created a portrait of this figure as an infant. A bronze cast by Lysippos inspired a statue by Glykon of the "Farnese" version of this figure.
answers: Zeuxis [or Self-Portrait as Zeuxis Portraying an Ugly Old Woman]
Aphrodite [or Aphrodite of Knidos; do not accept or prompt on Venus]

bonuses.leadin: The preface to Victor Hugo's massive verse play about this person served as a manifesto for a Shakespearean-style Romantic French drama. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this subject of Edmund Waller's earliest "Panegyrick" and Milton's sixteenth sonnet. Because he "could not cease in the inglorious arts of peace," this man is praised in a "Horatian Ode."
This Thomas Gray poem praises "some village-Hampden," "some mute inglorious Milton" and "some Cromwell guiltless of his country's blood."

The sources of Gray's elegy include this poet's "Monody on Queen Caroline." This poet's death titles a Gray sonnet that ends, "I fruitless mourn to him that cannot hear, and weep the more because I weep in vain."
answers: Oliver Cromwell [The last poem is by Andrew Marvell.]
"Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard" [John Hampden was Cromwell's cousin.]
Richard West [or "On the Death of Richard West"; or "Sonnet on the Death of Mr. Richard West"]
formatted_answers: Oliver Cromwell [The last poem is by Andrew Marvell.]
"Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard" [John Hampden was Cromwell's cousin.]

bonuses.leadin: This book contains the story of Nadab and Abihu, who were punished for offering a sacrifice with foreign fire. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book of the Bible concerned with purity. This third book of the Bible follows Exodus in the Pentateuch.

This section of Leviticus, roughly corresponding to chapters 17 through 26, may have been written separately from the rest of Leviticus. Named for a recurring word, this section contains the infamous command "[y]ou shall not lie with a male as with a woman; it is an abomination".

Due to its distinct style, the Holiness code has been a subject of scholarly debate over whether it belongs to this original text that emphasizes holiness. Along with the Yawhist source, this source makes up most of Genesis and Exodus.
answers: Book of Leviticus [prompt on the third book of Moses]

bonuses.leadin: In 1980, Erwin Chargaff refused permission to include his damning review of one of this scientist's books in a Norton Critical Edition of it. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this scientist, who repeatedly insults Rosalind Franklin throughout The Double Helix, which depicts his and Francis Crick's work on DNA.

The Critical Edition did, however, include this scientist's retrospective of the discovery of DNA. This scientist, who proposed a triple-helix structure of DNA, was largely mocked for writing books in which he claimed megadoses of vitamin C would cure the common cold.

The Critical Edition includes an analysis by this biologist, whose "pop science" books include Advice to a Young Scientist. This co-discoverer of acquired immune tolerance proposed the mutation accumulation theory of ageing.

bonuses.leadin: A work comparing these two characters uses the analogy of a midge sucking Alexander the Great's blood to illustrate beings that believe they are the center of creation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these two characters, one of whom "invents" and the other of whom "exploits what has been invented" according to an essay. That essay comparing these characters comments on how they were both created in the first decade of the 17th century.
That essay comparing "Hamlets" and "Don Quixotes" was written by this Russian author of Fathers and Sons.
Vasily Vasilyevich identifies himself as a "Hamlet" in the story "Hamlet of the Shchigrovsky District", which is part of this Turgenev collection based on experiences at his mother's estate.
answers: Hamlet and Don Quixote [answers may be given in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given]
A Sportsman's Sketches [or Zapiski Ohotnika; or A Sportsman's Notebook; or The Hunting Sketches; or Sketches from a Hunting Album]

A Sportsman's Sketches [or Zapiski Ohotnika; or A Sportsman's Notebook; or The Hunting Sketches; or Sketches from a Hunting Album]

bonuses.leadin: In 1957, Howard Zimmerman and Marjorie Traxler proposed a model in which certain aldol reactions pass through a transition state corresponding to this conformation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this most stable conformation of cyclohexane, which is adopted by almost all cyclohexane molecules at standard conditions.
The Zimmerman-Traxler model involves chair conformations produced during aldol reactions, during which bonds are formed between two atoms of this element central to organic chemistry.

The original paper on the Zimmerman-Traxler model applied it to the Ivanov reaction and to this other reaction named for a Russian chemist. In this reaction, aldehydes are condensed with alpha-halo esters to produce beta-hydroxy-esters, with help from a zinc catalyst.

bonuses.leadin: This company constructed Abraj Al-Bait (AA-braj ahl baa-EET), a seven-hotel complex that includes the Makkah Clock Royal Tower in Mecca. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this lead construction company for the in-progress, one-kilometer-tall Jeddah Tower. In 1964, this company was hired to replace the cladding on the Dome of the Rock during the period of Jordanian control of Jerusalem.

The founder of the Saudi Binaldin Group, Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden, was the father of Osama bin Laden, who founded this terrorist organization from the remnants of Maktab al-Khidamat (MAAK-tab al KEE-daa-mat) in the late 1980s.

In the 1980s, Osama bin Laden's mujahideen (MOO-juh-hah-DEEN) followers in Afghanistan received weapons and training from this Pakistani security agency, whose anti-Soviet program was assisted by the CIA in Operation Cyclone.
answers: Saudi Binladin Group [or SBG; or Binladin Group Global Holding Company]
formatted_answers: Saudi Binladin Group [or SBG; or Binladin Group Global Holding Company]

bonuses.leadin: The naven ritual of this island’s Iatmul people was described as a “vicious circle” in a 1936 book named for the rite that explained its function as keeping tensions from schismogenetic processes in check. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island whose Sepik basin is also home to the Arapesh, Mundugumor, and Tchambuli, whose gender roles were examined in the 1935 book Sex and Temperament in Three Primitive Societies.
This anthropologist, who wrote the book Naven, described communication issues resulting from “double binds” in Steps to an Ecology of Mind.
This author of Sex and Temperament and third wife of Bateson collaborated with him on Balinese Character and studied the sexual life of teenagers on Ta’u in Coming of Age in Samoa.
answers: New Guinea [or Papua; or Irian; or Niugini; reject “Papua New Guinea”]
formatted_answers: New Guinea [or Papua; or Irian; or Niugini; reject “Papua New Guinea”]

bonuses.leadin: A character in this film whistles the tune of a track titled for the woman he's having an affair with while shopping for an engagement ring. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1967 film that ends as a couple uses a massive crucifix to block a church door, enter a buzz, and then sit still during a long final shot of a bride. Linda Gray was paid $25 for a shot in this film of her leg arching over its main character.
This other Simon and Garfunkel song plays at the beginning and end of The Graduate. This song opens with the lyrics "Hello darkness, my old friend."
In a scene from The Graduate, Dustin Hoffman's character is pulled aside next to a pool and, with people socializing behind, is given a pitch about this word.

bonuses.leadin: Complete graphs with this property can be used to depict the results of a round-robin tournament. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property. Bayesian networks can be modeled by graphs that are both acyclic and have this property.
The final ranking of a round robin can be found by finding the "minimal" example of this set of arcs. These arc sets contain at least one edge from every cycle in the directed graph.

When breaking deadlocks, heuristics are preferable to finding minimal feedback arc sets as the latter task is in a complexity class named for these two letters and the word "hard." A Millennium Prize problem asks whether a class named for these two letters equals P.
answers: minimal feedback arc sets [or minimal feedback edge sets]
formatted_answers: minimal feedback arc sets [or minimal feedback edge sets]

bonuses.leadin: This group's name is sometimes used as an umbrella term for for all Jews of non-German or Eastern European origin, including the historically distinct Mizrahi (miz-RAH-hee). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Jewish group whose name derives from their original residence in the Iberian peninsula. They follow the unaltered Shulchan Aruch (SHOOL-hahn ah-ROOK) code.
Isaac Abarbanel's 30,000-ducat bribe to prevent this proclamation expelling the Sephardim fell through when Torquemada rebuked King Ferdinand with an analogy to Judas's thirty pieces of silver.

Albert Adatto attributes the fact that this state is home to America's largest Sephardic population outside of New York and Los Angeles to its "salt-water atmosphere." Prominent American Jews Howard Schultz and Jeffrey Brotman led businesses based in this state.

bonuses.leadin: The grammarian Festus tells of a column near the Temple of Pietas where it is thought that children were abandoned and women were hired to perform this action. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action which Uni performs for the demigod Hercle on a bronze mirror from Volterra. Pliny reports a painting in the Temple of Pietas depicting the story of "Roman Charity" in which Pero performs this action for her incarcerated father Cimon.
Rumina, a protectress of breastfeeding mothers, had her temple near the cave where this creature nursed Romulus and Remus.

The Columna Lactaria was probably maintained by worshippers who offered milk libations to Mercurius Sobrius, a syncretization of Mercury and a god of these people who worshiped Melqart. They may have practiced human sacrifice at tophets.
answers: breastfeeding [or nursing; or lactating; or clear equivalents about feeding someone with breastmilk; prompt on feeding]
Carthaginians [or people of Carthage; or Punic people; or Western Phoenicians]
formatted_answers: breastfeeding [or nursing; or lactating; or clear equivalents about feeding someone with breastmilk; prompt on feeding]
Carthaginians [or people of Carthage; or Punic people; or Western Phoenicians]

bonuses.leadin: Simon Putnam is assigned to edit a trashy novel about this couple in Francine Prose's book The Vixen. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this couple, whose tragic story is fictionalized in E.L. Doctorow's novel The Book of Daniel. In another work, one of them tells a dying lawyer, "I came here to forgive, but all I can do is take pleasure in your misery."

The narrator of this author's novel The Story of a Marriage clips out the bad news about the impending execution of the Rosenbergs from her husband's newspaper. This author won the 2018 Pulitzer Prize for the comic novel Less.
This Sylvia Plath novel opens with the line, "It was a queer, sultry summer, the summer they electrocuted the Rosenbergs."

bonuses.leadin: Composer and type of piece required. The fifth of these pieces, which its author revised as an audition for deputy Kapellmeister at the Imperial Court, is often linked to its composer's incomplete oratorio Lazarus due to its focus on death. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these pieces. An 1827 hymn cycle based on the poetry of Johann Philipp Neumann ("NOY-man") is often wrongly called the "German" one of them.
Shortly after completing his Mass No. 5, Schubert started writing his eighth symphony, which is now usually known by this nickname due to its fragmentary scherzo and missing trio.

Schubert wrote that Mass No. 5 in this key, which Beethoven used as the key for the slow sections of C-minor pieces like the Pathetique Sonata. Chopin's Heroic Polonaise is in this key, whose relative minor is F minor.
answers: masses by Franz Peter Schubert [both underlined parts required, prompt on partial; accept messe or missa in place of "mass"]
A-flat major [do not accept or prompt on "A"]
formatted_answers: masses by Franz Peter Schubert [both underlined parts required, prompt on partial; accept messe or missa in place of "mass"]
A-flat major [do not accept or prompt on "A"]

bonuses.leadin: Under Michael Savage, this country's welfare state was introduced in 1938 during its first Labour government. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country where the Muldoon government aimed at preserving infrastructural and welfare spending in the 70s through "Think Big" projects, which were later compared to a 2020 proposal by Jacinda (juh-SIN-duh) Ardern.

New Zealand reduced welfare spending in the 70s after its main trade partner, the UK, joined this organization. In 1967, this organization merged with "communities" dedicated to atomic energy and coal and steel.
Welfare spending was severely cut in the 90s in the "mother of all budgets" proposed by this Minister of Finance, whose name was combined with a term for assisted suicide to nickname the plan.

bonuses.leadin: Isaac Newton's estimate for this quantity was an underestimate by 15% because his theoretical work preceded the development of thermodynamics, so he tacitly assumed the process involved was isothermal. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity that can be measured in the lab with a Kundt's tube. This quantity, which is given by the Newton-Laplace ("lah-PLASS") equation, is often estimated as a constant plus "0.6 times temperature in Celsius."
Laplace's correction to Newton's original formula for the speed of sound in a fluid states that it equals this function of the bulk modulus K and the density rho. You have ten seconds.
All sound waves in a fluid are this type of wave, which oscillate parallel to their propagation direction. These waves are contrasted with transverse, or shear, waves.
answers: square root of K over rho [accept to the power one-half in place of "root;" accept divided by in place of "over;" accept bulk modulus in place of K; accept density in place of "rho"]
formatted_answers: square root of K over rho [accept to the power one-half in place of "root;" accept divided by in place of "over;" accept bulk modulus in place of K; accept density in place of "rho"]

bonuses.leadin: Fernando Tarrida del Marmol's dissatisfaction with conflicts between adherents of various forms of this ideology led him to coin and promote a variety "without adjectives." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this political philosophy whose various forms all advocate a stateless society.

This earliest self-proclaimed anarchist declared that "property in theft!" in his book What is Property? Karl Marx inverted the subtitle of a book by this thinker in a response titled The Poverty of Philosophy.

This adjective describes Proudhon's ideal form of market socialism, which "synthesizes communism and property." This adjective appears in the English title of an essay by Peter Kropotkin that argues that evolution is driven by cooperation rather than competition.
answers: anarchism [or word forms such as anarchy; or anarchism without adjectives]
mutual [or mutualism; or mutualist anarchism; or Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution]
formatted_answers: anarchism [or word forms such as anarchy; or anarchism without adjectives]
mutual [or mutualism; or mutualist anarchism; or Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution]

bonuses.leadin: One character states that 98.4% of all people who die in a specific month will turn into these objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects that title a play which opens with the Hippie Boy and Girl sniffing glue. One of these objects is actually the father of a child on the roof in the Kobo Abe play The Man Who Turned into [one of these objects].

In The Man Who Turned into a Stick, a man and a woman from this place attempted to buy the stick off of the hippies. An artist completes a work depicting this place after the Grand Lord burns a carriage containing his daughter and a monkey.
Kobo Abe hails from this Asian country that developed noh and kabuki theater.
answers: sticks [accept The Man Who Turned into a Stick; accept Bo Ni Natta Otoko]
hell [accept Man or Woman from Hell; accept "Hell-Screen"; accept "Jigokuhen"]
formatted_answers: sticks [accept The Man Who Turned into a Stick; accept Bo Ni Natta Otoko]
hell [accept Man or Woman from Hell; accept "Hell-Screen"; accept "Jigokuhen"]

bonuses.leadin: In 2022, this state's Department of Human Services sued former professional wrestler Ted DiBiase and football Hall of Famer Brett Favre for inappropriately receiving funds from welfare. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this state whose former governor Phil Bryant was implicated in a welfare funds misappropriation scandal centering on the pharmaceutical company Prevacus.

In 2022, Mississippi failed to pass one of these legislations "for Parents" that would have created a "right to information" about school materials. Limits on tax and spending in Colorado originate from one of these legislations "for Taxpayers."
Current Mississippi Governor Tate Reeves signed a bill that established a new state flag in the aftermath of protests after this Minnesota man was murdered by police officer Derek Chauvin.
answers: Bill of Rights [or Parents' Bill of Rights; or Parental Bill of Rights; or Taxpayer's Bill of Rights]
formatted_answers: Bill of Rights [or Parents' Bill of Rights; or Parental Bill of Rights; or Taxpayer's Bill of Rights]
